questions.text: Match the following concerning duodenal atresia: Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-2, B-3, C-1

Highyeild:

Duodenal Atresia : Most common forms of intestinal obstruction in the newborn The obstruction in duodenal atresia usually lies just distal to the ampulla of Vater. The proximal duodenum and pylorus dilate with swallowed amniotic fluid, rendering the pylorus temporarily incompetent. Types : Type I duodenal atresia – Obstructing web formed from mucosa and submucosa with no defect in muscularis. Type II duodenal atresia – Short fibrous cord connecting two blind ends of duodenum. There is no defect in the mesentery. Type III duodenal atresia – No connection between the two ends of the duodenum. V-shaped defect in mesentery Diagnosis : Occasionally, there is a web that may stretch like a windsock. If suspected antenatally, duodenal atresia is confirmed postnatally on an abdominal radiograph, showing a ‘double bubble’ , if missed, it presents with bilious vomiting. The hepatopancreatic duct may have openings on either side of the atresia, and a little gas can pass distally. Treatment : Open Kimura duodenoduodenostomy with or without a trans-anastomotic tube.

questions.text: Which of the following is the screening investigation of choice for Hirschprung’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anorectal Manometry The screening investigation of choice for Hirschprung’s disease is Anorectal Manometry . Digital Rectal examination is the first investigation to be done in suspected cases of Hirschprung’s disease to differentiate it from functional constipation DRE is followed by a barium enema to look at the transition zone and dilated part of the bowel Rectal biopsy is the confirmatory investigation for Hirschprung’s disease.

Highyeild:

Genetic defects (e.g. RET, EDNRB, EDN3) can affect the migration of neural crest-derived intestinal neurones (neurocristopathy), leading to aganglionosis and thickened nerve trunks in the distal bowel. Clinical Presentation : Delayed passage of meconium Abdominal distension and Bilious vomiting Diagnosis : Cot-side suction rectal biopsy. Contrast enema Daily rectal washouts Decompression Stoma is fashioned using frozen section histopathology Treatment Options: Swenson, Duhamel, Yancey–Soave and transanal ‘pull-throughs’ are options.

Extraedge:

Adult Hirschsprung’s disease is a very rare disease and leads to a megarectum because the afected segment is ‘ultrashort’, afecting only the transition zone of the anus. Histologically, this is very difcult to diagnose with certainty and some challenge its existence at all.

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: A. Rectal biopsy should be taken within 2cm of the dentate line
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rectal biopsy should be taken within 2cm of the dentate line Rectal biopsy should be taken 2 cm above the dentate line as the part within 2 cm of the dentate line is physiologically aganglionic. Gene mutations have been identified on chromosome 10 (involving RET proto-oncogene) and on chromosome 13 Hirschprung’s disease may be familial or associated with Down’s syndrome or other genetic disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about exomphalos?

options.label: B
options.text: A component of the Pentalogy of Cantrell

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Associated with intestinal atresia Corrected Statements : Exomphalos is associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome It is a component of the Pentalogy of Cantrell, which also includes anterior diaphragmatic hernia, sternal cleft, ectopia cordis and intracardiac defects Gastroschisis, and not exomphalos, is associated with intestinal atresia Exomphalos is covered by the amniotic sac

Highyeild:

Exomphalos describes a central abdominal wall defect in which prolapsed viscera are covered in a thin, three-layered membrane (peritoneum, Wharton’s jelly and amnion) in continuity with the umbilical cord. Exomphalos minor (<5 cm, liver not involved) is commonly associated with other anomalies and the defect is easily closed. In exomphalos major the sac can be dressed with a topical antibacterial agent (e.g. manuka honey, silver sulfadiazine), allowing epithelialisation and later closure of the ventral hernia. If an early closure of an exomphalos major is attempted, close observation for an abdominal compartment syndrome is mandated.
